metadata.title: Balneotherapy -Pain – included tender point count, V AS, and total pressure pain thresholds with a dolorimeter on tender points -Depression – Beck Depression Inventory and Hamilton Depression Rating Scale -Pulmonary functions were determined with dyspnea scale and a spirometer –Results -All groups showed improvement at the end of the treatment (3 weeks) -The modalities plus balneotherapy group had significant improvements in dyspnea scale score and spirometric measures at 6-month  follow-up.  Pain and depression evaluation assessments were also improved in this group at 6-month follow-up -Authors caution that the small sample size might have influenced the results and that larger patient groups are necessary to substantiate these outcomes •Pain, mood, sleep, and depression(4) –Authors have concluded that balneotherapy combined with a physical therapy program can improve self-reported  sleep and reduce nocturnal pain in patients with OA(16) –Authors of a study of a 12-day  balneotherapy program indicated that the program had a positive effect on pain, mood, sleep, and depression in healthy older adults(4) -Fifty-two  healthy older adults participated in a study in Spain -Hypothermic hard water with bicarbonate, sulfate, sodium, and magnesium was used for balneotherapy -Pain was measured via V AS, mood was measured with the Profile of Mood Status, sleep was assessed via the Oviedo Sleep Questionnaire, and depression was measured using the Geriatric Depression Scale -Balneotherapy produced significant improvements in all outcome measures. Men had a significant improvement in pain reduction and women showed a significant improvement in depression and fatigue –Pain perception and quality of life was used to assess short- and long-term  effects of spa therapy by researchers in Poland who studied 70 patients aged 60 years and older with OA(13) -Spa treatment was for 15 sessions over a period of 3 weeks consisting of 120–150  minutes per day of physical agent modalities, kinesiotherapy, massage, peloid therapy, crenotherapy, and hydrotherapy with mineral waters -Laitinen scale, V AS, and WHOQOL-BREF  questionnaire reported significant improvements in short-term  (3 months) as well as long-term  (12 month) follow-up -Pain perception was decreased, and quality of life in the domain of social relations and the environment improved –Authors of an RCT conducted in Lithuania compared balneotherapy to music therapy or no therapy at all. The balneotherapy group reported improvements in reducing stress and fatigue. The balneotherapy group received 108 g/L salinity geothermal water baths 5 times per week for 2 weeks(7) –Stress level, systolic blood pressure, state of mood, and subjective relaxation improved when physical activity was combined with balneotherapy(8) -Based on an RCT in Austria of 81 healthy adults who completed four types of 1-hour,  short-term interventions for stress reduction -Participants with high reported stress levels had decreased systolic blood pressure and felt more alert after a combination of walking and balneotherapy –Balneotherapy combined with a psychoeducation program can be an effective treatment method for patients with a benzodiazepine addiction(15) •Researchers in China found significantly improved blood cell count and biochemical indexes and reduced ponogen (waste matter produced by exertion) levels after a 21-day  balneotherapy program(11)    –Study included 129 servicemen in “sub-health”  condition –Subjects were divided into a balneotherapy group for full-body  immersion in thermomineral water for 30 minutes daily and a control group immersed in tap-water  baths –Blood samples were drawn 1 day before the start of treatment and 22 days after treatment •Authors of a systematic review of literature from 1998 to 2014 on the effects of balneotherapy for patients with RA concluded that there continues to be insufficient evidence on the efficacy of balneotherapy compared to no treatment(14) . Desired Outcomes/Outcome Measures
description: Balneotherapy is the use of mineral baths to reduce pain and improve the sense of well-being

Theoretical rationale for the therapeutic use of balneotherapy –Balneotherapy may generate mechanical, chemical, and physical effects in a treated extremity, with the goal being reduction in pain and an improved sense of well-being(17) –Balneotherapy may lead to local hyperthermia, improved circulation, and muscle relaxation. There may be an increase in the activity of the lymphatic system and stimulation of the immune system, which might lead to decreased inflammation(11) –Chemical effects of mineral salts and gaseous compounds (e.g., sulfur and carbon dioxide) absorbed through the skin may cause vasodilation(11) –Immersion in mineral bath water reduces loading on joints(11)
indications: Indicated to decrease pain and improve sense of well-being

CPT codes.There: are no CPT codes for balneotherapy

reimbursement: Coverage varies with insurance plans, depending on diagnosis and the reason specific treatment is required. There might be limitations, such as number of treatments per condition or per time period
The treating clinician is advised to check with the patient’s specific carrier to obtain reimbursement information
In some European countries such as France, spa therapy treatment programs may be reimbursed by social security(18) Indications for Procedure
contraindications precautions to test: Record adverse reaction to water immersion/therapy, if present

indications for procedure: Balneotherapy is used to treat the following conditions: Pain(4,11) Muscle spasms(11) Joint movement disorders(11) Depression(4) Anxiety(7) Stress(8) Mild hypertension(7) Dermatological conditions  Allergic rhinitis(12)

Goals of balneotherapy Relieve muscle spasms(11) Maintain or improve functional mobility(11) Reduce stiffness(11) Reduce pain(11) Reduce loading on joints(11) Improve microcirculation(11) Heighten sense of well-being(8) Reduce allergy symptoms(12)

contraindications precautions to examina: Record adverse reaction to water immersion/therapy, if present

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Identify reason for referral -Examination varies based on reason for referral

course of treatment.medical management: What medical procedures, diagnostic tests, surgeries, complications, and/or hospital stays has the patient had? What treatments have helped? What treatments have not? Medical management varies depending on underlying condition/reason for referral
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Diagnostic tests vary depending on nature of condition
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any noted aggravating or easing factors
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any history of respiratory compromise, supplemental oxygen use, or need for mechanical ventilation? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the patient had a previous episode of presenting problem?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other health concerns, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders. Ask about conditions that are contraindications/precautions for balneotherapy
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Does the patient work or attend school?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Include limitations with self-care, home management, work, and/or community leisure
social and occupational history.living environment: Document information about the living environment including stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (e.g., caregivers, family members). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Evaluation procedures should be modified according to patient’s age, diagnosis, and any unique circumstances; the information presented below is meant to serve as a guide only. Following completion of a land-based  evaluation, the patient’s water safety (e.g., ability to place feet on pool bottom when immersed in water on request) and motor skills need to be assessed in the mineral bath
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Circumference for swelling, peripheral edema, and joint swelling
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient require the use of any assistive or adaptive devices?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess the patient’s balance in sitting and standing
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess peripheral pulses and compareObserve general body mechanics, which might contribute to the patient’s symptoms throughout the assessment
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess transfers and mobility as indicated by underlying condition
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Evaluate the patient’s gait as indicated by reason for referralAssess integrity of involved joints as indicated by reason for referralComplete a muscle tone and/or coordination assessment as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Complete a thorough strength assessment as indicated and appropriate. Use dynamometer and pinchometer for hand strength assessment where indicated
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess posture in static and dynamic situations
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Complete a full active and passive ROM and flexibility assessment as indicated and appropriate
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess reflexes bilaterally and compareAssess ADLs as indicated
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Complete a thorough sensory assessment (e.g., light touch, pin prick, hot/cold)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests are specific to the diagnosis
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Complete a cognitive assessment as indicated and appropriate. Is the patient able to communicate that he or she is uncomfortable or in pain?

other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Close supervision during balneotherapy is required, particularly with whole-body  immersion, as there is a risk of drowning. Appropriate precautions to prevent falls should be taken (e.g., use nonslip mats, avoid walking on wet, slick surfaces, supervise patient in and out of therapy pools)

Patients who have a diagnosis for which this intervention is used might be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/ caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies
Medical clearance is recommended for patients with cardiovascular concerns prior to full-body  immersion balneotherapy

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: There are numerous indications for balneotherapy; please see Indications for procedure , above. Diagnoses for which balneotherapy might be indicated include: Osteoarthritis (OA)(3) Rheumatoid arthritis(17)  Ankylosing spondylitis(11) Fibromyalgia(17) Low back pain(11) Depression(1,4) Psoriatic arthritis(11)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to other disciplines as indicated and appropriate
treatment summary: Authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis  in Hungary investigated the benefits of hydro-  and balneotherapy(3) –All clinical trials were conducted in Hungarian thermal mineral waters –The systematic review included 18 clinical trials. Data from 1,199 subjects (patients and controls) were evaluated –The meta-analysis  included 9 of the 18 clinical trials –Patients were treated for various conditions including knee OA, hand OA, chronic low back pain, cervical and lumbar degenerative disease, and chronic pelvic inflammatory disease –Study limitations included small sample size of studies, heterogeneous populations, diversity of methodology, and diversity in outcome measures –The authors concluded that Hungarian thermal mineral waters significantly reduced pain in patients with OA of the hand and knee, degenerative joint and spinal disease, and chronic low back pain. Additional high-quality  studies are warranted

Arthritis –Balneotherapy proved to be effective in the treatment of knee OA by reducing pain, functional limitations, NSAID consumption, and improving quality of life of affected patients(9) -Based on a systematic review of 12 studies published between 2002 and 2017 on mud-pack  therapy, balneotherapy, spa therapy, and mud-bath  therapy in the treatment of knee OA –Balneotherapy, along with physical therapy, was shown to be more effective in improving functional outcomes and pain management for individuals with severe knee OA than physical therapy alone(6) -Researchers from Turkey studied the effects of balneotherapy and physical therapy in 46 patients (10 males, 36 females) with severe knee OA -Patients were assigned to either the physical therapy group or the balneotherapy plus physical therapy group -Outcome measures used for this study included the V AS for pain, Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Arthritis Index (WOMAC), and 10-meter  walking test -All patients received hotpacks, TENS, and ultrasonography of the knee for 45 minutes, 5 days per week for 3 weeks -Additionally, those in the balneotherapy group also received balneotherapy for 20 minutes, 5 days per week for 3 weeks -Results at the end of the study show both groups receiving benefits from their respective treatment for pain and functional mobility; however, patients who also received balneotherapy had significant improvements in all outcome measures compared with physical therapy alone –In a cost-effectiveness  analysis, mud-bath  therapy, in addition to usual treatment, improved quality-adjusted  life years and lowered the direct cost per patient in the management of patients with bilateral knee OA(10) -Based on an RCT performed in Italy in which 103 patients were followed over 12 months with the EuroQol 5-Dimension  questionnaire and direct cost consumption data per patient -Costs were higher in the control group (those patients who did not have mud-bath  therapy) because of the use of intraarticular hyaluronic acid and/or hospitalization for total knee arthroplasty

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) –Clinical trials with solid methodology of the use of balneotherapy for patients with rheumatoid arthritis are lacking(5) –Authors of a 2015 Cochrane review investigated the effects of balneotherapy in patients with RA(5) -Nine studies involving 579 participants met inclusion criteria -Most studies showed methodological flaws and an unclear risk of bias in many domains. Data and information regarding trial design were often lacking -Results -A low level of evidence supports balneotherapy over drug therapy for treatment of pain -A moderate level of evidence supports additional radon in carbon dioxide baths for management of RA symptoms -Most studies report positive outcomes but do not provide sufficient evidence or adequate statistical analysis  -Additional large, high-quality,  low-bias  studies are warranted to provide evidence for the effects of balneotherapy

Fibromyalgia –Balneotherapy in patients with primary fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS) may result in improvement compared with control groups for the symptoms of pain, depression, and breathing(1) –Based on an RCT conducted in Turkey –Fifty-six  patients with FMS were divided into three groups of similar age, sex, and duration of illness –All three groups received the same physical therapy modalities of TENS, ultrasound (US), and infrared heat (IR). One group received the modalities only, the second group received the modalities plus balneotherapy, and the third group received the modalities plus hydrotherapy –Outcome -Pain – included tender point count, V AS, and total pressure pain thresholds with a dolorimeter on tender points -Depression – Beck Depression Inventory and Hamilton Depression Rating Scale -Pulmonary functions were determined with dyspnea scale and a spirometer –Results -All groups showed improvement at the end of the treatment (3 weeks) -The modalities plus balneotherapy group had significant improvements in dyspnea scale score and spirometric measures at 6-month  follow-up.  Pain and depression evaluation assessments were also improved in this group at 6-month follow-up -Authors caution that the small sample size might have influenced the results and that larger patient groups are necessary to substantiate these outcomes

Pain, mood, sleep, and depression(4) –Authors have concluded that balneotherapy combined with a physical therapy program can improve self-reported  sleep and reduce nocturnal pain in patients with OA(16) –Authors of a study of a 12-day  balneotherapy program indicated that the program had a positive effect on pain, mood, sleep, and depression in healthy older adults(4) -Fifty-two  healthy older adults participated in a study in Spain -Hypothermic hard water with bicarbonate, sulfate, sodium, and magnesium was used for balneotherapy -Pain was measured via V AS, mood was measured with the Profile of Mood Status, sleep was assessed via the Oviedo Sleep Questionnaire, and depression was measured using the Geriatric Depression Scale -Balneotherapy produced significant improvements in all outcome measures. Men had a significant improvement in pain reduction and women showed a significant improvement in depression and fatigue –Pain perception and quality of life was used to assess short- and long-term  effects of spa therapy by researchers in Poland who studied 70 patients aged 60 years and older with OA(13) -Spa treatment was for 15 sessions over a period of 3 weeks consisting of 120–150  minutes per day of physical agent modalities, kinesiotherapy, massage, peloid therapy, crenotherapy, and hydrotherapy with mineral waters -Laitinen scale, V AS, and WHOQOL-BREF  questionnaire reported significant improvements in short-term  (3 months) as well as long-term  (12 month) follow-up -Pain perception was decreased, and quality of life in the domain of social relations and the environment improved –Authors of an RCT conducted in Lithuania compared balneotherapy to music therapy or no therapy at all. The balneotherapy group reported improvements in reducing stress and fatigue. The balneotherapy group received 108 g/L salinity geothermal water baths 5 times per week for 2 weeks(7) –Stress level, systolic blood pressure, state of mood, and subjective relaxation improved when physical activity was combined with balneotherapy(8) -Based on an RCT in Austria of 81 healthy adults who completed four types of 1-hour,  short-term interventions for stress reduction -Participants with high reported stress levels had decreased systolic blood pressure and felt more alert after a combination of walking and balneotherapy –Balneotherapy combined with a psychoeducation program can be an effective treatment method for patients with a benzodiazepine addiction(15)

Researchers in China found significantly improved blood cell count and biochemical indexes and reduced ponogen (waste matter produced by exertion) levels after a 21-day  balneotherapy program(11)  –Study included 129 servicemen in “sub-health”  condition –Subjects were divided into a balneotherapy group for full-body  immersion in thermomineral water for 30 minutes daily and a control group immersed in tap-water  baths –Blood samples were drawn 1 day before the start of treatment and 22 days after treatment

Authors of a systematic review of literature from 1998 to 2014 on the effects of balneotherapy for patients with RA concluded that there continues to be insufficient evidence on the efficacy of balneotherapy compared to no treatment(14) . maintenance or prevention: Six weeks of treatment with balneotherapy might be sufficient to achieve an improvement that can last up to 6 months(2) Factors leading to compliance –Availability of mineral bath pools –Individual’s perception that the balneotherapy sessions were beneficial Factors leading to noncompliance –Cost –Transportation issues –Individual’s perception that the balneotherapy sessions were not beneficial Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
